'''Stephen Mack Stigler''' (born August 10, 1941) is Ernest DeWitt Burton [[Distinguished Service Professor]] at the Department of [[Statistics]] of the [[University of Chicago]].<ref>Catherine Behan (May 28, 1998) [http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/980528/stigler.shtml 1998 Quantrell Award: Stephen Stigler] University of Chicago Chronicle. 17(17).</ref> He was born in Minneapolis.<ref>[http://books.google.ca/books?id=7Q80AAAAIAAJ&q=%22Stigler,+stephen+mack%22+1941&dq=%22Stigler,+stephen+mack%22+1941&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AuGYUey7HsSniAK3x4GYAw&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ]</ref> His research has focused on statistical theory of [[robust statistics|robust estimators]] and the [[history of statistics]].  He is also known for [[Stigler's law of eponymy]].

His father was the [[economist]] [[George Stigler]], and he has recently<ref>http://www.stat.uchicago.edu/~stigler/2014websscv.pdf</ref> written on [[Milton Friedman]], who was a friend of his father.

Stigler received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in 1967 from the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. His dissertation was on [[linear function]]s of [[order statistics]], and his advisor was [[Lucien Le Cam]].

Stigler taught at [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] until 1979 when he joined the University of Chicago. In 2006 he was elected to membership of the [[American Philosophical Society]], and is a past president (1994) of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]].
